thread.title: How Cats lessen the reliance on ‘Dangerwood’
thread.title_full: How Cats lessen the reliance on ‘Dangerwood’

title: How Cats lessen the reliance on ‘Dangerwood’
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS PATRICK Dangerfield’s arrival at Geelong was designed to relieve the pressure on Joel Selwood. 
Yet, as often became the case throughout 2016, it instead shifted the focus of the side’s reliance upon the shoulders of the man who would ultimately go on to claim the Brownlow Medal. 
While the pair became arguably the competition’s most dynamic and influential on-ball duos, it was evident they were susceptible to being overwhelmed by deeper midfield groups. 
Such deficiencies were particularly exposed against Sydney in last year’s preliminary final, where Geelong conceded seven first-quarter goals and trailed by 39 points at the opening change. 
From there, the match was over, with Geelong’s soft underbelly brutally exposed by the Swans. 
Now, in order to improve on last season and take the next step to what the club hopes will be a fourth premiership in a decade, the Cats’ new breed must stand up to be counted. 
HELPING ‘DANGERWOOD’ 
CLEARLY, Dangerfield and Selwood need some support. 
The pair had an immense impact on not only each other last year, but also the team, helping the Cats improve to a 17-5 record in the home-and-away season. 
Ranking 18th for clearances and 15th for contested possessions across 2015, Geelong clearly needed help prior to the arrival of Dangerfield. Those numbers subsequently improved to sixth and fifth respectively in the year after he joined from Adelaide. 
But together with Selwood, the pair combined for 34.7 per cent of all clearances won by the side and 20.1 per cent of all contested possessions — too high an amount for just two players. 
As a result, the difference between the side’s best and worst was pronounced. And the reason for that was the team’s lack of a second-tier through the midfield to aid its impressive double-act. 
According to Champion Data , Geelong ranked No.1 in the league against fellow top eight rivals throughout 2016, but the worst of all finals teams against bottom 10 opposition. 
Defeats to the likes of Carlton, Collingwood and St Kilda were low points on the season, but convincing victories over Hawthorn, the Western Bulldogs and Greater Western Sydney showed just how good the Cats could be when they were at their best. 
The key to Chris Scott building the foundations for a successful premiership run now lies in closing the gap between the good and the bad. Mitch Duncan could be one to step up in 2017. Source: Getty Images 
However, as Champion Data explored in its 2017 AFL Prospectus , the chasm between Dangerfield, Selwood and the rest in Geelong’s midfield is becoming increasingly pronounced. 
The pair are the only two Cats midfielders classified by Champion Data as ‘elite’, with no on-ballers on the club’s entire list ranking as ‘above average’ — the next category down. 
That class gap was evidenced further on the club’s best and fairest night. With Dangerfield and Selwood a clear first and second, third place was claimed by the recently retired Corey Enright. 
Mitch Duncan (eighth) was the only other out-and-out midfielder to secure a top 10 finish. 
With that said, the onus now falls on a host of players to take up the slack. 
Live stream EVERY game of the JLT Community Series on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW > 
FILLING THE VOID 
FORTUNATELY for the Cats, there are players waiting in the wings to take the next step. 
Mitch Duncan, Cam Guthrie and Mark Blicavs are classified as the next tier of midfielders behind Dangerfield and Selwood — and all three have pathways to improve in 2017. 
All eyes might be focused on Duncan, now 25, taking the big leap next season. 
He averaged career-high numbers in disposals, tackles and inside 50s last year, but saw his goalkicking output dip. 
Having kicked 87 goals across his first five years in the AFL system, Duncan showed he was a capable of impacting on the scoreboard from the middle. 
However, he hasn’t hit double figures in his last two seasons. 
Still rated at league average by Champion Data , he is looming as the clear candidate to aid ‘Dangerwood’ in 2017 and help bridge the side’s midfield class gap. 
Guthrie is coming off a career year, where he spent his time playing both through the midfield and across half back, averaging 22.9 disposals per game. Cam Guthrie had a career-best year in 2016. Picture: Wayne Ludbey.   
In the All-Australian conversation at the midway point of the year, his form plateaued across the second half of the season. However, expected to receive more midfield minutes in 2017, there’s no reason Guthrie can’t be the player to go to another level. 
Remarkably, at 198cm and 100kg, Blicavs evolved into a full-time midfielder in 2016. 
He averaged 17.8 disposals and 5.8 tackles per game, with his elite fitness levels aiding his mobility around the ground. 
The competition’s most prolific player from third-man up ruck opportunities, the abolition of such situations from the game will present the versatile Cat with more chances to effect the game on ground level — provided he does not transition into a permanent ruckman. 
However, given his ability to play anywhere on the field, don’t rule that out. 
PROVIDING THE DEPTH 
WHILE the next tier of elite midfielders might emerge for Geelong in 2017, depth remains crucial. 
You only have to look at what the Western Bulldogs achieved last year, despite a host of injury issues, to see the value of building a deep on-ball group. 
Scott Selwood, Sam Menegola and Josh Cowan arrived on the scene late in the year for differing fitness reasons, but will hopefully play a more key role in the side’s upcoming campaign. 
Selwood struggled with injury but is an experienced head who will get better with more minutes, Menegola had an immediate impact following his debut, while Cowan was clean on the outside. 
All three should benefit from a full pre-season under their belts. 
And while Josh Caddy’s defection to Richmond — and the missed recruitment of Brett Deledio in return — might hurt initially, the Cats have a batch of young offensive-minded midfielders who will be looking to make their spot in the side their own. 
Former top 10 draft pick Nakia Cockatoo is one who has shown glimpses of his talent, but has frustrated in equal measure across his short Geelong career. It’s been a similar story for Darcy Lang, who has found himself on the fringes of the best 22. 
Steven Motlop and Daniel Menzel can rotate through the midfield, but will play predominantly forward, while it’s too early to judge what Pick 26 Brandan Parfitt will add in his rookie year. 
All are capable of making some sort of impact in 2017. Though more than just Dangerfield and Selwood will have to hit the ground running if Geelong is to prove itself the real deal.
